title: 108_hr4124
content: The "Medical Malpractice Relief Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It introduces a credit for qualified expenditures for medical professional malpractice insurance under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Medical Malpractice Relief Act of 2004 introduces a tax credit for qualified medical malpractice insurance expenditures for eligible persons. The credit is limited to twice the average costs of insurance for similarly situated individuals. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with relevant state boards, determines the average costs. The Medical Malpractice Relief Act of 2004 introduces a tax credit for qualified medical malpractice insurance expenditures for eligible persons. The Secretary determines average costs of insurance and eligible persons must certify these costs annually. Definitions and special rules apply for qualified medical malpractice insurance expenditures. The Medical Malpractice Relief Act of 2004 offers a tax credit for medical malpractice insurance expenditures for eligible persons, including physicians in various specialties and hospitals or clinics. Eligible persons must certify their costs annually. The Medical Malpractice Relief Act of 2004 provides a tax credit for medical malpractice insurance expenditures for eligible healthcare providers, with varying applicable percentages based on the type of provider. The determination of whether providers are similarly situated is based on medical practices within a statistical area and considers specialty and subspecialty practices. The Medical Malpractice Relief Act of 2004 offers a tax credit for medical malpractice insurance expenses for eligible healthcare providers, based on specialty and subspecialty practices. The act includes provisions for electing not to claim the credit and terminates for taxable years after December 31, 2005. Additionally, the credit is integrated into the general business credit under Section 38(b) of the tax code. The tax code is amended to prevent the carryback of medical malpractice insurance expenditure tax credit before January 1, 2004. Additionally, no deduction is allowed for the portion of qualified medical malpractice insurance expenditures equal to the credit allowable for the taxable year. The tax code is amended to prevent the carryback of medical malpractice insurance expenditure tax credit before January 1, 2004. Grants will be awarded to non-profit hospitals, clinics, and long-term care providers by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible non-profit hospitals, clinics, and long-term care providers to help cover medical malpractice insurance costs. To qualify for a grant, an entity must be a non-profit organization exempt from tax under section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible non-profit hospitals, clinics, and long-term care providers to help cover medical malpractice insurance costs. The grant amount will be 15 percent of the qualified medical malpractice insurance expenditures incurred by the entity. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to non-profit hospitals, clinics, and long-term care providers to cover medical malpractice insurance costs. The grants will not exceed twice the average costs for similar entities, with appropriations authorized for fiscal years 2005 and 2006. The amendments made by this section regarding the credit for expenditures for medical professional malpractice insurance will apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003.
